column1: Intestinal ischemia and infarction is damage to (ischemia) or death of (infarction) part of the intestine.
- Adhesions: The intestine may become trapped in scar tissue from past surgery (adhesions).
- Embolus: A blood clot from the heart or main blood vessels may travel through the bloodstream and block one of the arteries supplying the intestine.
People who have had a heart attack or who have arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation, are at risk for this problem.
- Venous thrombosis: The veins carrying blood away from the intestines may become blocked by blood clots This interrupts blood flow in the intestines.
This is more common in people with liver disease, cancer, or blood clotting disorders.
The main symptoms of intestinal ischemia is abdominal pain.
Laboratory tests may show a high white blood cell (WBC) count (a marker of infection) and increased acid in the bloodstream.
Other tests include: - Angiogram - CT scan of the abdomen - Doppler ultrasound of the abdomen These tests do not always diagnose the problem.
Intestinal ischemia is a serious condition that can result in death if not treated promptly.
People who have a large amount of tissue death in the intestine can have problems absorbing nutrients.
Some people may become severely ill with fever and a bloodstream infection (sepsis).
Call your health care provider if you have any severe abdominal pain.
